European structural steel standard EN 10025 : 2004 Explanation and comparison to previous standards
Introduction
EN 10025 : 2004 is the new European standard for structural steel. EN 10025 : 2004 is the new European standard for
The new standard EN 10025 : 2004
structural steel. This leaflet shows the new grades,
The new standard is published in six parts and draws
properties and the nearest equivalent grades from
together earlier standards to produce one standard for
former standards including EN 10025 : 1993. The grade
the majority of structural steel products. The parts are:

History of the standard The European Committee for Iron and Steel
• Part 4 - Technical delivery conditions for
Standardisation is responsible for producing the
thermomechanically rolled weldable fine grain
European Standards (ENs) for structural steels. The first
structural steels.
of these standards, EN 10025, was published in the UK
Supersedes EN 10113 : parts 1 & 3 : 1993
by BSI as EN 10025 : 1990, partly superseding BS 4360 : 1986, which was re-issued as BS 4360 : 1990.
• Part 5 - Technical delivery conditions for structural
In 1993, a second edition of EN 10025 was made
steels with improved atmospheric corrosion
available together with EN 10113 : parts 1, 2 & 3 and EN
resistance - also known as weathering steels.
10155. In June 1994, EN 10210 : part 1 was published
Supersedes EN 10155 : 1993
and at the same time BS 4360 was officially withdrawn. The balance of the BS 4360 steels not affected by these
• Part 6 - Technical delivery conditions for flat products
ENs were re-issued in new British Standards BS 7613
of high yield strength structural steels in the quenched
and BS 7668. In 1996, with the publication of EN 10137,
and tempered condition.
BS 7613 was withdrawn. BS 7668 will remain until an
Supersedes EN 10137 : parts 1 & 2 : 1996
EN for atmospheric corrosion resistant hollow sections is available. In 2004 the standard EN 10025 was revised to address the provisions of EU Construction Products Directive (89/106/EEC). It is now published in six parts to bring together almost all the ‘Structural Metallic Products’ into one comprehensive standard.

Notes 1 For all products to be compliant with the EU Construction Products Directive (CPD 89/106/EC) the material must offer a guaranteed minimum impact performance. This has resulted in the removal of this grade from the standard, and the lowest grade now offered is the JR version for each yield strength variation. 2 Verification of the specified impact value is only carried out when agreed at the time of the enquiry and order.
